header_summary:
Bitcoin developers are advancing transaction privacy through Payjoin transactions and the innovative Octojoin method, which mixes Unspent Transaction Outputs (UTXOs) from multiple participants to obscure transaction histories. Octojoin draws inspiration from an octopus's ability to camouflage, aiming to integrate privacy-enhanced transactions with regular bitcoin activities seamlessly. This approach not only complicates transaction tracing for analysts but also introduces new possibilities for users to engage in swaps and sell statecoins from coinjoined UTXOs, with further information and participation opportunities detailed on the [Octojoin official page](https://octojoin.github.io/).

The release of Bitcoin Core version 26.2 marks a milestone in the cryptocurrency's development, incorporating new features, bug fixes, and performance improvements to enhance user experience and system efficiency. Available for download at [Bitcoin Core](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-26.2/), this update extends compatibility across various operating systems and introduces changes in script handling and networking. The update is a testament to the collaborative effort within the open-source community, encouraging user feedback via the project's GitHub issue tracker to refine and address potential issues.

A novel cryptographic development, the LS-LSAG logarithmic-size ring signature scheme, presents a significant breakthrough in blockchain security and efficiency. Detailed in a draft for community review at [https://eprint.iacr.org/2024/921](https://eprint.iacr.org/2024/921), this scheme reduces the signature size drastically without compromising security, leveraging an inner-product argument in a prime-order group of elliptic curve points. Designed for unforgeability based on the Discrete Logarithm assumption, LS-LSAG aims to offer a secure, efficient alternative for cryptographic applications, emphasizing its potential impact on blockchain technologies and beyond.

recent_posts.title: Octojoin: Payjoin with no interaction between sender and recipient
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin developers are addressing privacy issues in transactions through Payjoin and Octojoin.
- Octojoin uses multiple inputs in transactions to mask ownership, mimicking an octopus's camouflage.
- It aims to improve privacy, increase swaps usage, and facilitate statecoins sales from coinjoined UTXOs.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 26.2 released
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 26.2 is now available for download, offering new features and bug fixes.
- Users are advised to shut down older versions completely before upgrading to ensure smooth transition.
- The release introduces script adjustments, peer-to-peer network enhancements, and RPC modifications for improved functionality.

recent_posts.title: A new logarithmic-size signature scheme LS-LSAG
recent_posts.summary:
- Ed Hughes introduces a novel log-size ring signature scheme, LS-LSAG, for blockchain enhancement.
- The scheme is detailed online for community feedback, promising significant size efficiency improvements.
- LS-LSAG, compatible with Curve Trees, offers a groundbreaking, secure alternative to LSAG/CLSAG signatures.

active_posts.title: Proposing a P2QRH BIP towards a quantum resistant soft fork
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal highlights the need for quantum resistance in Bitcoin through a new signature algorithm.
- It introduces a series of Bitcoin Improvement Proposals for the "QuBit" soft fork to combat quantum vulnerabilities.
- The document encourages community feedback to refine and advance these quantum-resistant measures.

active_posts.title: Public disclosure of 10 vulnerabilities affecting Bitcoin Core < 0.21.0
active_posts.summary:
- A new vulnerability disclosure policy has been implemented to enhance security measures.
- The project's official website now features 10 security advisories for public view.
- Planned disclosures for vulnerabilities in previous versions start in July, promoting transparency.

active_posts.title: BIP Draft: "ChillDKG: Distributed Key Generation for FROST"
active_posts.summary:
- Tim, Jonas, and Nick draft a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal on FROST Threshold Signatures.
- Their draft includes design details, usage instructions, and a Python reference implementation.
- They seek feedback on GitHub, with aspects like the wire format and test vectors under development.

active_posts.title: Segwit Ephemeral Anchors
active_posts.summary:
- Ephemeral Anchors offer a way to use "dusty" values but rely on Bitcoin's old script system.
- An initial solution using `wsh(OP_TRUE)` is deemed inefficient and expensive.
- A new proposal suggests using bip141 with "OP_TRUE 0xffff" for efficiency, implemented on a special branch.

active_posts.title: Ephemeral Anchors and MEVil
active_posts.summary:
- An anomaly in blockchain's "anti-MEVil" mechanism allows manipulation of transaction ordering through increased ephemeral anchor values.
- The example shows 'Bob' using 'Alice's funds to conflict with `TxD`, depicted in a flowchart with four specific transactions.
- Anti-DoS rules inadvertently motivate this manipulation, altering transaction validation by incentivizing artificial conflict creation.

active_posts.title: Stable Channels - peer-to-peer dollar balances on Lightning
active_posts.summary:
- Stable Channels integrates bitcoin with the Lightning network for dollar stability and reduced volatility.
- It enables direct settlements without banks, enhancing both stability and self-custody in cryptocurrency transactions.
- The project explores expanding into other assets and integrating with eCash, despite facing operational challenges.

today_in_history_posts.title: Schnorr signatures BIP
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Russell O'Connor suggests changing a verification equation to improve efficiency.
- The modification eliminates the need for negating a point or coefficient.
- This change simplifies the verification process by removing one negation operation.

today_in_history_posts.title: proposal for Lightning Network improvement proposals
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- René Pickhardt proposed creating Lightning Network Improvement Proposals (LIPs) similar to BIPs.
- LIP-0001 draft, mirroring BIP-0002, aims to organize enhancement ideas for BOLT1.1.
- Potential LIP topics include watchtowers, autopilot, AMP, and splicing, with Pickhardt focusing on Splicing.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's scalability involves creating 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks" for mass transactions.
- Tools like OP_VAULT and initiatives like BIP324 aim to secure and scale Bitcoin efficiently.
- Networking off-chain entities with regulatory compliance tools is critical for Layer 1 interaction.
